description: System-generated unique identifier for the part record.
Primary manufacturer or catalog identifier used to source and reference the part across vendors and systems.
Warehouse or storeroom where the part’s inventory is maintained.
Short, human-readable name of the part for display and selection.
General item type classification used for categorization and business rules (e.g., standard items, tires).
Stocking status indicating whether the item is kept on hand versus non-stock or special-order.
Category grouping for reporting, spend analysis, and maintenance classification.
Code of the preferred supplier used by default when creating purchase orders.
Detailed or extended description of the part; often longer than the display name.
Specific shelf or bin identifier within the storeroom where the item is stored.
Secondary storage location for overflow or alternate bin, if applicable.
Maximum desired on-hand quantity used by min/max replenishment logic.
Minimum desired on-hand quantity (safety stock) that helps trigger replenishment.
On-hand quantity at which a reorder should be initiated.
Expected time between placing an order and receiving the item, typically in days.
Time unit or cycle for the lead time value (e.g., days, weeks); confirm with SME.
Average operating time between failures for this item, used for reliability planning.
Time unit for mean time between failures (e.g., hours, days); confirm with SME.
Indicates whether the system automatically creates orders when reorder criteria are met.
Indicates whether barcode labels should be printed for this item.
Factor dividing quantity to determine barcode units or label count; usage may vary—confirm with SME.
Unit of measure used when purchasing the item from suppliers.
Unit of measure used when issuing the item to work orders or vehicles.
Conversion factor between order and issue units (issue units per order unit).
Indicates whether the part is exempt from sales or use tax.
Current on-hand quantity available in the storeroom.
Markup applied when charging out the item; may represent amount or percentage—confirm with SME.
Standard unit cost or price used for valuation and billing; source may vary—confirm with SME.
Shipping cost associated with procuring the item; may be applied at line or item level—confirm with SME.
Tax associated with the item on purchase or issue; may be amount or rate—confirm with SME.
Title or subject line for the associated part notes.
Free-text comments about the item, such as charges, handling, or compatibility.
